item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:24, topic:418833”][quote author=R.I.P RSC link=topic=521370.msg3791441#msg3791441 date=1319320696]

Hi My Name Is RIP RSC And I Like To Overcomplicated A Joke To Make It Not As Funny

Hi My Name Is Davidi2 And I Like To Changed The Pronunciation Of Words And Names In A Way That Makes Them Sound Funny
[/quote]Even if that was true, I don’t see what’s wrong with it? The point of the joke is the way he said it and cracked up, not the actual name pronunciation… :L[/quote]

I know, if you don’t care about my discussion with mopman then just read over our posts. Like I said in my first post in this thread, it’s funny. If you pronounce it the English way, her name is indeed hilarious. But the last time I checked, we at least try to pronounce the names of foreigners in the way the foreigners pronounce it. Mopman and I discussed the proper way of doing that.

Read full topic

item.title: Best OHGODDONTLAUGH face ever
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

Davidi2:

Hi My Name Is RIP RSC And I Like To Overcomplicated A Joke To Make It Not As Funny

Hi My Name Is Davidi2 And I Like To Changed The Pronunciation Of Words And Names In A Way That Makes Them Sound Funny

[quote=“Mopman, post:22, topic:418833”][quote author=R.I.P RSC link=topic=521370.msg3791151#msg3791151 date=1319304528]
You do know that the Netherlands is a sovereign country right? It’s not part of Germany
[/quote]

I am not going to dignify that question with a response

As to the German, next time I hear it I’ll post it here and you can tell me how close to Dutch Ik it is

The high german Ich is actually a voiceless palatal fricative (ç), not x … and no, I dunno who the fuck comes up with the terminology for this stuff[/quote]

It’s actually quite interesting stuff though. To see (or hear) the different ways of pronouncing the same 26 letters of our alphabet. I bet you’ll never guess the right pronunciation of the Frisian word for grass, ‘gers’.

Read full topic

item.title: Best OHGODDONTLAUGH face ever
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

en.wikipedia.org

Standard German phonology

The phonology of Standard German is the standard pronunciation or accent of the German language. It deals with current phonology and phonetics as well as with historical developments thereof as well as the geographical variants and the influence of German dialects. While the spelling of German is officially standardised by an international organisation (the Council for German Orthography) the pronunciation has no official standard and relies on a de facto standard documented in reference works su...

I’ve never heard a German pronounce Ich like we Dutch speakers pronounce Ik. Do you mean Ik as in Dick? Germens either say Ich with a ‘voiceless velar fricative’ (just found it on wikipedia, http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voiceless_velar_fricative) or with a 'voiceless palato-alveolar sibilant (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voiceless_palato-alveolar_sibilant who comes up with these names?) Never with a 'voiceless velar plosive (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voiceless_velar_plosive)

You do know that the Netherlands is a sovereign country right? It’s not part of Germany

Read full topic

item.title: Best OHGODDONTLAUGH face ever
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

[quote=“R.I.P RSC, post:18, topic:418833”][quote author=Mopman link=topic=521370.msg3790139#msg3790139 date=1319233738]
Wouldn’t the “German way” be dependant on where in Germany they live? Like how Ich is pronounced either Ik or Ish depending on region?
[/quote]

The ‘ch’ in Ich is pronounced in an other way than ‘ch’ at the beginning of a word. In Bayern you have a region called the ‘Chiemgau’ (great holiday location btw! Chiemsee, Chiemgauer Alpen etc). It’s pronounced like ‘Kiemgau’, like the ‘ch’ in Chrysler.[/quote]

True, but then you’ve got words like der Chirurg, which I would pronounce “sh-eer-urg” - is this wrong? (Also, it’s really hard to write pronunciation without knowing IPA, I really should learn that one day :/)

R.I.P RSC:

I doubt Germans pronounce Ich like ‘Ik’ or with a really hard G like we have in Dutch. Maybe some Germans give it a slight ‘Dutch sound’, but it’s almost always close to ‘Ish’.

It varies, but there are definitely some regions where it’s pretty much “Ik”. I don’t know enough about the German speaking world to know which regions it is, but everytime I hear it it kinda makes me go o_O

Read full topic

item.title: Best OHGODDONTLAUGH face ever
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

Mopman:

Wouldn’t the “German way” be dependant on where in Germany they live? Like how Ich is pronounced either Ik or Ish depending on region?

The ‘ch’ in Ich is pronounced in an other way than ‘ch’ at the beginning of a word. In Bayern you have a region called the ‘Chiemgau’ (great holiday location btw! Chiemsee, Chiemgauer Alpen etc). It’s pronounced like ‘Kiemgau’, like the ‘ch’ in Chrysler.

I doubt Germans pronounce Ich like ‘Ik’ or with a really hard G like we have in Dutch. Maybe some Germans give it a slight ‘Dutch sound’, but it’s almost always close to ‘Ish’.

I made a small mistake though. I said a long e as in e-book, I meant the ‘e’ sound as in way.

Read full topic

item.title: Best OHGODDONTLAUGH face ever
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:10, topic:418833”]Really? That’s how I’d pronounce it, too, though with a harder ch rather than a British sounding sh, but that’s a pretty subtle difference.

How should it be pronounced?[/quote]

The ‘ch’ in the Czech language (Chmelar is a Czech word, not German) is pronounced similar to the hard g in the Dutch word ‘ga’, which means go. We don’t pronounce the g the same was as we pronounce it in ‘goal’, but like this: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YLTQv8RH1TE (1:06) So it would be something like ‘Gmeeeeeeeelar’ (long e like in e-book instead of the short e in seller)

If the Germans decided to pronounce her name in the German way, it sounds like Kmelar, like the K sound in clan.

Read full topic
